questions.text: All of the following are associated with an increased risk of developing Perthes’ disease of the hip in childhood except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Congenital muscular torticollis Congenital muscular torticollis is associated with developmental dysplasia of the hip and not with Perthes’ disease.

Highyeild:

Congenital Torticollis (Infantile torticollis, Sterno-mastoid tumour) The sterno-mastoid muscle on one side of the neck is fibrosed and fails to elongate as the child grows, and thus results in a progressive deformity. The cause of fibrosis is not known, but it is possibly a result of ischaemic necrosis of the sterno-mastoid muscle at birth. Evidence in favor of this theory is the presence of a lump in the sterno-mastoid muscle in the first few weeks of life, probably a swollen ischaemic muscle. This is termed sterno-mastoid tumour. The lump disappears spontaneously within a few months, leaving a fibrosed muscle. Torticol- lis occurs more commonly in children with breech presentation. Diagnosis: The child usually presents at 3-4 years of age, often as late as puberty. The head is tilted to one side so that the chin faces to the opposite side (Fig-39.1). The sterno-mastoid is prominent on the side the head tilts, and becomes more prominent on trying to passively correct the head tilt. In cases presenting in the first few weeks of life, a lump may be felt in the sterno-mastoid muscle. Facial asymmetry develops in cases who present later in life. Radiological examination is normal, and is carried out to rule out an underlying bone defect such as scoliosis. questions.text: A 12-year-old obese boy is brought to the OPD with complaints of a fall one day back and pain in the right hip radiating to the thigh and back. An X-ray revealed a slipped capital femoral epiphysis. His blood parameters were normal. Which of following the condition needs to be ruled out?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypothyroidism There is an increased risk of slipped capital femoral epiphysis in associated endocrine diseases like thyroid disorders and obesity . Etiology: In majority → Remains unknown Mechanical factors Endocrinal factors Genetic - Thinning of perichondrial ring complex. - Retroversion of femoral neck - Change in inclination of adolescent proximal physis in relation to neck and shaft. - Imbalances - Thyroid growth, sex hormone - Chronic renal failure - Klinefelter syndrome - Turner syndrome - 1° Hypoparathyroidism

questions.text: A 9-year-old male with pain in left hip & limping. There is a history of fall in the park around one month back. On examination there is restricted abduction & internal rotation, the probable diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Perthes disease It can be defined as osteochondritis of the proximal femoral epiphysis in a growing child Signs: Painful limp, antalgic or Trendelenburg (Positive on effect side), atrophy of gluteal, quadriceps, and hamstring muscles. Movement of abduction and internal rotation is restricted

Highyeild:

Clinical Presentation M:F3-5:1 It is usually bilateral and in 10-12% cases and familial in 10% There may be h/o antecedent trauma (often a fall or twisting) several months earlier. Symptom - limp - most -pain - 2nd most in the groin, anterior hip region, or laterally around greater trochanter and referred to knee. Signs: Painful limp, antalgic or trendelenburg (Positive on effect side), atrophy of gluteal, quadricepes and hamstring muscles. Movement of abduction and internal rotation is restricted

questions.text: Perthe’s disease is treated by which of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: High dose of calcium with steroids

options.label: C
options.text: Containment of the femoral head in the acetabulum

questions.correct_answer: C. Containment of the femoral head in the acetabulum
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Containment of the femoral head in the acetabulum The primary aim of treatment is to prevent deformity to the femoral head before the remodeling phase and 'containment' of the femoral head

Highyeild:

Perthe’s Disease Treatment The main aim of treatment is containment of the femoral head in the acetabulum. Non surgical containment is achieved by orthotic braces All braces abduct the affected hip, most allow for hip flexion, and some control rotation of the limb. Surgical containment is through femoral varus derotation osteotomy, innominate osteotomy, valgus osteotomy, shelf arthroplasty, chiari osteotomy and cheilectomy (surgically removing protruding fragments of femoral head usually antero lateral).

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy, 55 kg weight with rapid gain in height since last 11 months has complaints of inability to sit with legs crossed and difficulty in squatting. On bending his knee, it reaches the axilla on the same side. What’s the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis Slipped capital femoral epiphysis – Age of 11 years, thin tall child (growth hormone disorder), inability to sit with legs crossed and difficulty in squatting and axis deviation sign positive is suggestive of SCFE

Highyeild:

Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis/Epiphysiolysis This is wrong term as the epiphysis doesn't slip. During a period of rapid growth, due to weakening of upper femoral physis shearing stress from excessive body weight, there is upward & anterior movement of femoral neck on the capital epiphysis. So the epiphysis displaces primarily posteriorly relative to the femoral neck. Incidence male: female 3:2 Classification Acute SCFE: Prodromal symptom for 3 weeks or less presenting as sudden fracture like episode after minor trauma. It is usually a salter type I injury and AVN is a significant complication Chronic SCFE: it is the most frequent form, an adolescent patient presenting with vague groin pain upper and lower thigh pain and limp Acute on chronic SCFE: In this prodromal symptoms are more than 3 weeks with sudden exacerbation of pain. Aetiology The cause is unknown in vast majority of patients. A. Mechanical factors ● Thinning of perichondrial ring complex ● Retroversion of Femoral neck ● Change in inclination of adolescent proximal physis relative to femoral neck and shaft B. Endocrine ● Imbalance of thyroid growth and sex hormone ● Chronic renal failure ● Kleinfeilter syndrome ● Turner syndrome ● Primary hypo parathyroidism C. Genetic Examination: ● The leg is found to be externally rotated and 1-2 cm short. ● Limitation of hip movements is characteristic - there is limited abduction and internal rotation, with a corresponding increase in adduction and external rotation. ● AXIAL DEVIATION - When the hip is flexed, the knee goes towards the ipsilateral axilla ● Muscle bulk may be reduced. ● Trendelenburg's sign may be positive. Examination: The leg is found to be externally rotated and 1-2 cm short. Limitation of hip movements is characteristic - there is limited abduction and internal rotation, with a corresponding increase in adduction and external rotation. When the hip is flexed, the knee goes towards the ipsilateral axilla (Fig-39.5). Muscle bulk may be reduced. Trendelenburg's sign may be positive.

questions.text: The most common complication following treatment of acute slipped capital femoral epiphysis is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Avascular necrosis The most signiﬁcant risk associated with SCFE is avascular necrosis of the femoral head. Surgical complications include chondrolysis and early osteoarthritis secondary to screw penetration. Avascular necrosis of the head of the femur

Perthes disease Boy with restriction of abduction and internal rotation, is suggestive of Perthes disease
